# B Proofs
## B. 1 Section 2.1 Proofs

Proof of Proposition 1. Lemma 5 shows that the conditional expectation $\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(\Delta_{i}\right) \mid \hat{\Delta}_{i}\right]$ is monotone increasing in $\hat{\Delta}_{i}$. As a result, there exists a constant $c$ such that

$$
\hat{\Delta}_{i} \geq c \Leftrightarrow \mathbb{E}\left[u\left(\Delta_{i}\right) \mid \hat{\Delta}_{i}\right] \geq 0
$$

Because $1-\Phi(x)$ is decreasing, there exists a threshold $\alpha$ such that

$$
1-\Phi\left(\frac{\hat{\Delta}_{i} \sqrt{n}}{\sigma}\right) \leq \alpha \Leftrightarrow \mathbb{E}\left[u\left(\Delta_{i}\right) \mid \hat{\Delta}_{i}\right] \geq 0
$$

as desired.

# B. 2 Section 2.2 Proofs 

Proof of Theorem 1. Reparametrize the optimization problem by the variable $x=N / i$. This yields

$$
F(I, N)=N \max _{x \in\left[\frac{N}{I}, N\right]} \frac{f(x)}{x}
$$

Next, we claim that the function $g(x):=f(x) / x$ on $\mathbb{R}^{+}$is unimodal: it is positive everywhere, increasing on $\left[0, x^{*}\right]$ and decreasing to zero on $\left[x^{*}, \infty\right]$. If this is true, it is clear that Eq. (8) holds.

Positivity is clear. To prove the other claim, first note $g$ is smooth and $g^{\prime}(x)=\frac{x f^{\prime}(x)-f(x)}{x^{*}}$. Thus it suffices to show there exists an $x^{*}$ such that $h(x):=x f^{\prime}(x)-f(x) \geq 0$ on $\left[0, x^{*}\right]$ and is non-positive on $\left[x^{*}, \infty\right)$. The derivative of $h$ is equal to $x f^{\prime \prime}(x)$. Recall that Proposition 2 of [AMOV23] shows there exists $\hat{x}$ for which $f(x)$ is convex on $[0, \hat{x}]$ and concave on $[\hat{x}, \infty)$. Thus, $h$ is increasing on $[0, \hat{x}]$ and is decreasing on $(\hat{x}, \infty)$. Finally, note the following two properties of $h$.

1. $h(0) \geq 0$. Interpret $h(0)$ as the limit of the derivative $x f^{\prime}(x)$ as $x \rightarrow 0^{+}$. A straightforward calculation shows that this exists; see also Proposition 1 of $\left[\mathrm{ADMO}^{+} 20\right]$. Further it is nonnegative as $f^{\prime}(x) \geq 0$ for all $x \geq 0$.
2. $\liminf _{x \rightarrow \infty} h(x)<0$. since $f(x)$ is increasing and bounded above, $g(x)$ is decreasing for large $x$. Thus, for $x$ large enough, $h(x)$ is negative.

By the intermediate value theorem, there exists such a $x^{*}$, greater than $\hat{x}$.
Proof of Corollary 1. For the first part, $F_{1}(I)$ is increasing by a coupling argument: any testing strategy for $I$ ideas is admissible for $I^{\prime}>I$ ideas. Now consider the following two cases. If $N \leq x^{*}$, then the function is constant and equal to $f(N)$. Otherwise Theorem 1 implies

$$
F_{1}(I)= \begin{cases}I f\left(\frac{N}{I}\right) & \text { if } I \leq \frac{N}{x^{*}} \\ N \frac{f\left(x^{*}\right)}{x^{*}} & \text { if } I \geq \frac{N}{x^{*}}\end{cases}
$$

For $I$ larger than $\frac{N}{x^{*}}$, the function is constant. Otherwise, the function $g(I, N)=\operatorname{If}\left(\frac{N}{I}\right)$ is the perspective transform of $f$. Since $I \in\left[1, \frac{N}{x^{*}}\right]$, the argument $\frac{N}{I}$ lies in $\left[x^{*}, N\right]$. The proof of Theorem 1 shows that $x^{*} \geq \hat{x}$, and so $f$ is concave on $\left[x^{*}, N\right]$. Since the perspective function of a concave function is concave, we conclude that $F_{1}(I)$ is concave.

For the second part, recall that $x^{*}$ is independent of $I, N$. It only depends on the underlying distribution $G$. Re-expressing the result of Theorem 1 gives

$$
F_{2}(N)= \begin{cases}f(N) & \text { if } N \leq x^{*} \\ N \frac{f\left(x^{*}\right)}{x^{*}} & \text { if } N \in\left[x^{*}, I x^{*}\right] \\ I f\left(\frac{N}{I}\right) & \text { if } N \geq I x^{*}\end{cases}
$$

Using the fact that $\hat{x} \leq x^{*}$, the desired properties are now easy to see.
Proof of Corollary 2. $L_{1}$ is equal to $c I-F(I, N)$, where $c=\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta_{i}^{+}\right]$is explicit. By Theorem 1,

$$
L_{1}= \begin{cases}c I-f(N) & \text { if } x^{*} \geq N \\ c I-N \frac{f\left(x^{*}\right)}{x^{*}} & \text { if } x^{*} \in\left[\frac{N}{I}, N\right] \\ I\left(c-f\left(\frac{N}{I}\right)\right) & \text { if } x^{*} \leq \frac{N}{I}\end{cases}
$$

Since $N \rightarrow \infty$ and $N / I \rightarrow \kappa$, only the second and third cases are relevant. If $\kappa \leq x^{*}$ then eventually $x^{*} \in[N / I, N]$, and so $L_{1}=c I-N \frac{f\left(x^{*}\right)}{x^{*}}$. In this regime, $L_{1} / I \rightarrow c-\kappa \frac{f\left(x^{*}\right)}{x^{*}}$. The other case is similar, using continuity of $f$.

Proof of Corollary 3. This leverages Prop. 4 of [AMOV23]; the result states that $\frac{\partial f}{\partial \mu}>0$ if and only if $\mu<0$, and $\frac{\partial f}{\partial \tau}>0$. By Theorem $1, F(I, N)$ for fixed $I, N$ is some positive multiple of $f$ with argument depending on $I, N$. Hence it is also increasing as $\mu \uparrow 0, \tau \rightarrow \infty$.

# B. 3 Section 5 Proofs 

Lemma 4. The minimax risk is bounded below by the Bayes risk of any prior.
Proof. For any decision $\delta, \sup _{\theta^{\prime}} R\left(\theta^{\prime}, \delta\right) \geq R(\theta, \delta)$. Taking the expectation over $\theta \in G$ for some prior $G$, we find

$$
\sup _{\theta^{\prime}} R\left(\theta^{\prime}, \delta\right) \geq \mathbb{E}_{\theta} R(\theta, \delta)
$$

Thus $\sup _{\theta^{\prime}} R\left(\theta^{\prime}, \delta\right) \geq \inf _{\delta^{\prime}} \mathbb{E}_{\theta} R\left(\theta, \delta^{\prime}\right)$, and now taking the inf over the left hand side over $\delta$, we conclude

$$
\inf _{\delta} \sup _{\theta^{\prime}} R\left(\theta^{\prime}, \delta\right) \geq \inf _{\delta^{\prime}} \mathbb{E}_{\theta} R\left(\theta, \delta^{\prime}\right)
$$

which shows that the minimax risk is bounded below by the Bayes risk over any prior.
Proof of Prop. 2. Firstly, the maximum risk of the decision rule to ship when $X_{i}>0$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \max _{\mu_{i}} \sum_{i} \mu_{i}^{+}-\mu_{i} \Phi\left(\frac{\mu_{i} \sqrt{n_{i}}}{\sigma}\right) \\
= & \sum_{i} \max _{\mu_{i}>0} \mu_{i}\left(1-\Phi\left(\frac{\mu_{i} \sqrt{n_{i}}}{\sigma}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall from Lemma 4 that the minimax risk is bounded below by the Bayes risk for any prior. Consider a prior where $\mu_{i}$ are all i.i.d. and take values $\pm C_{i}$ with probability $1 / 2$. By independence, the Bayes optimal rule is to apply the Bayes rule for a single test individually. The Bayes risk is then given by the sum of the Bayes risks for the single test decision problem.

For a single test decision problem, the optimal decision rule is to ship if $X_{i}>0$ : writing out an explicit formula for the posterior mean shows $\mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i} \mid X_{i}=0\right]=0$ and the posterior mean is increasing. The Bayes risk of the single procedure is then $\mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{+}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i} \mathbf{1}\{X>0\}\right]$, which can be computed as

$$
\frac{C_{i}}{2}\left(1-\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{N}\left(0, \sigma^{2} / n_{i}\right) \in\left[-C_{i}, C_{i}\right]\right)\right)
$$

This simplifies to $C_{i}\left(1-\Phi\left(\frac{C_{i} \sqrt{n_{i}}}{\sigma}\right)\right)$. Picking the parameters $C_{i}$ to maximize the Bayes risk, the resulting quantity is

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \max _{C_{i}>0} C_{i}\left(1-\Phi\left(\frac{C_{i} \sqrt{n_{i}}}{\sigma}\right)\right)
$$

which exactly matches the risk of the posited decision rule.

Proof of Lemma 3. The expression for the minimax risk is given in the proof of Prop. 2. We claim that the function

$$
g(n)=\max _{\mu>0} \mu\left(1-\Phi\left(\frac{\mu \sqrt{n}}{\sigma}\right)\right)
$$

is concave decreasing. The decreasing property is simple to see, since the function $f_{n}(\mu)=$ $\mu\left(1-\Phi\left(\frac{\mu \sqrt{n}}{\sigma}\right)\right)$ is uniformly smaller as $n$ increases. To see concavity, change variables in the maximization by using $\nu=\mu \sqrt{n} / \sigma$, so that

$$
g(n)=\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \max _{\nu>0} \nu(1-\Phi(\nu))=C / \sqrt{n}
$$

for some constant $C>0$. Combined with the fact that $n_{i} \geq 1$ (otherwise the minimax risk would be infinite), the problem becomes a convex optimization problem symmetric in the variables, showing that equal allocation reduces the minimax risk.

# B. 4 Misc. Computations 

Lemma 5 (Monotonicity of the Posterior Expectation). Let $F$ be an increasing function. Suppose $\mu \sim G$, with $\int|F(x)| d G(x)<\infty$, and $X \sim N\left(\mu, \sigma^{2}\right)$. Then the conditional expectation $\mathbb{E}[F(\mu) \mid X=$ $x]$ is increasing in $x$.

Proof of Lemma 5. The conditional expectation can be written out explicitly as

$$
\frac{\int F(\mu) \phi\left(\frac{\mu-x}{\sigma}\right) d G(\mu)}{\int \phi\left(\frac{\mu-x}{\sigma}\right) d G(\mu)}
$$

By the dominated convergence theorem, using the boundedness of the Gaussian density, the quantity is differentiable in $x$. The derivative is a positive constant times

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \phi\left(\frac{\mu-x}{\sigma}\right) d G(\mu) \int F(\mu)(\mu-x) \phi\left(\frac{\mu-x}{\sigma}\right) d G(\mu) \\
& -\int F(\mu) \phi\left(\frac{\mu-x}{\sigma}\right) d G(\mu) \int(\mu-x) \phi\left(\frac{\mu-x}{\sigma}\right) d G(\mu)
\end{aligned}
$$

Renormalizing by another positive constant, this is equal to

$$
\mathbb{E}[F(\mu)(\mu-X) \mid X]-\mathbb{E}[\mu-X \mid X] \mathbb{E}[F(\mu) \mid X]
$$

Since $F(\mu)$ and $\mu-x$ are increasing in $\mu$, the Harris-FKG inequality shows that this expression is positive. Thus, the derivative is positive.

abstract:
Experimentation in online digital platforms is used to inform decision
making. Specifically, the goal of many experiments is to optimize a metric of
interest. Null hypothesis statistical testing can be ill-suited to this task,
as it is indifferent to the magnitude of effect sizes and opportunity costs.
Given access to a pool of related past experiments, we discuss how
experimentation practice should change when the goal is optimization. We survey
the literature on empirical Bayes analyses of A/B test portfolios, and single
out the A/B Testing Problem (Azevedo et al., 2020) as a starting point, which
treats experimentation as a constrained optimization problem. We show that the
framework can be solved with dynamic programming and implemented by
appropriately tuning $p$-value thresholds. Furthermore, we develop several
extensions of the A/B Testing Problem and discuss the implications of these
results on experimentation programs in industry. For example, under no-cost
assumptions, firms should be testing many more ideas, reducing test allocation
sizes, and relaxing $p$-value thresholds away from $p = 0.05$.
